Mathematical Reflection Implementation Investigation 2

The Mathematical Reflection provides an opportunity to discuss the goals of the Investigation. Students can pull together their reasoning from the Now What Do You Know to summarize their learning over the time (Time).

After the class discussion, students can record their responses to the Mathematical Reflection to create a record of their current understandings of the big ideas of the Unit.

A teacher can gain an understanding of student thinking during a discussion of the reflection question. Then one can assess individual understanding based on each student’s written work.
AoL: Surface Areas and Volumes of Three-Dimensional Shapes including Polygonal Prisms: Analysis

Mathematical Reflection

What do you know about measurements of two- and three-dimensional shapes?

Emerging Mathematical Ideas

Volume and surface area of right prisms and slicing rectangular prisms have been the focus of Investigation 2.

Students’ knowledge on measurement of two- and three-dimensional shapes will include:

  • finding the surface area of a triangular prism, a square prism, a pentagonal prism, a hexagonal prism and an octagonal prism with the same height
  • finding the volume of a triangular prism, a square prism, a pentagonal prism, a hexagonal prism and an octagonal prism with the same height
  • knowing that as the number of sides of right prisms with the same height increase the volume increases
  • solving real world problems involving volume of right prisms
  • using nets of right prisms to find volume and surface area of the prisms
  • describing finding the volume of right prism as finding the number of unit cubes in the prism
  • describing finding the volume of right prism as finding the area of the base and multiplying it by the height
  • describing finding the volume of right prism as Area of Base x height or V = Bh
  • knowing how to cut a square prism with the minimum number of cuts to make a triangular prism, pentagonal prism, and hexagonal prims
  • being able to analyze drawings of rectangular prisms that have been cut from different angles and predict the shapes that are created

Student Responses

Each Investigation contributes to students’ conceptual understandings of the ideas in the Unit. Students’ explanations at the beginning of a Unit might be just forming. As you progress through the Unit, students can use the contexts, representation, and connections to express a more solid understanding. By the end of the Unit, students can create a complete picture of understanding.

What do you know about measurements of two- and three-dimensional shapes?

(At this point students can talk add to these ideas to their Investigation 1 thoughts: finding the volume of all right prisms by calculating the area of the base times the height; the volume of right prisms increases as the number of sides increases; and how to create various shapes by slicing a rectangular prism.)

Reflecting on Student Learning

Use the following questions to assess student understanding at the end of the lesson.

  • What in evidence in students’ work shows an understanding the ideas in this Unit?
  • What mathematical ideas will still need emphasis?
  • What opportunities exist in the rest of the Unit, or in future Units, to extend and connect the students’ learning?
